Title.evidence: Goal-Directed Fluid Management in Neurosurgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: randomly assigned them to goal-directed (n=240) or routine fluid management (n=240) using block randomisation with concealed allocation

Participants.evidence: We enrolled 480 adults aged 18–65 years, scheduled for elective glioma resection at a single hospital

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received 3 ml/kg hydroxyethyl starch when stroke volume variation exceeded 15% for 5 minutes

Objective.evidence: assessed the impact of goal-directed fluid management on postoperative brain edema

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was cerebral edema volume within 24 hours post-surgery, assessed by CT

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: using block randomisation with concealed allocation

Blinding.evidence: Patients, outcome assessors, and follow-up assessors were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between November 2018 and September 2022, 480 patients were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 239 in the goal-directed group and 240 in the routine group, using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant difference in brain edema volume was observed (36.0 vs. 38.9 cm³, mean difference: 0.18 cm³, 95% CI: −5.7 to 5.9, P=0.938)

Harms.evidence: No significant differences were found in Karnofsky Performance Status at 30 days or in adverse events between groups

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered at clinicaltrials.gov (NCT03323580)

Funding.evidence: funded by the Beijing Municipal Administration of Hospitals Incubating Program
